tossups.question: I·COLLs are “intermittently closed” to sources of high values for this quantity. The viral shunt recycles organic matter in systems with high values for this abiotic quantity. Densities characterize the Ghyben–Herzberg relation’s description of “intrusion” by components with high values for this quantity, which may take the form of “wedges” that go against the flow. Systems characterized by intermediate values of this quantity can prevent its increase by being “bar-built.” (*) Estuaries feature gradients of this quantity that increase towards the mouth. Gradients of temperature and this quantity drive thermohaline circulation. For 10 points, name this quantity that is intermediate in brackish water and high in seawater.
tossups.answer: salinity [or salt concentration or salt content]
tossups.metadata: David Bass, Science - Earth> ~28667~ <Editor: David Bass

tossups.question: An ode by this poet asks a city “What angel is hidden in your cheek?” A poem by this author declares “the dove and the leopard fought” and “a boy brought the white sheet.” Another poem by this author describes “the ship out on the sea / and the horse on the mountain,” and a woman “with eyes of cold silver” dreaming on her balcony. This author of Poet in New York declares (*) “Green, how I want you green” in “Romance Sonámbulo.” This poet repeats “at five in the afternoon” in “Lament for the Death of a Bullfighter,” and wrote a play in which The Moon watches Leonardo flee with the Bride. For 10 points, name this member of the Generation of ’27, whose Rural Trilogy includes The House of Bernarda Alba and Blood Wedding.
tossups.answer: Federico García Lorca [accept Federico del Sagrado Corazón de Jesús García Lorca]
tossups.metadata: Jaimie Carlson, Literature - European - Poetry> ~28696~ <Editor: Jaimie Carlson

tossups.question: One of these objects turns back time when reverting arrows to canebrakes and birds. A text named for one of these objects coined the maxim “as above, so below.” The Anzu steals one of these objects from a bathing Enlil, resulting in Ninurta being sent to retrieve it. During the war to avenge Abzu, this type of object acts as Kingu’s breastplate. The philosopher’s stone is described by (*) Hermes Trismegistus in an “Emerald” text named for this type of object. Marduk claims one of these objects of “destiny” after slaying Tiamat. The Epic of Gilgamesh was discovered on some of these objects taken from Ashurbanipal’s library. For 10 points, reed-pen styluses inscribed Mesopotamian myths on what clay writing medium?
tossups.answer: tablet [accept Tablet of Destinies or Tablets of Destiny; accept Emerald Tablet; prompt on Emerald by asking “what other object”; prompt on slab]
tossups.metadata: Kevin Thomas, RMP - World Mythology> ~27151~ <Editor: Kevin Thomas

tossups.question: People suffering from this disease were treated by the Australian bush nurse Sister Kenny. Over 200,000 “pioneers” received a placebo as part of a nationwide trial of a treatment for this disease developed at the University of Pittsburgh. 44 people were infected by this disease due to faulty practices from Berkeley’s Cutter Labs. Dr. Hart E. Van Riper warned against this disease’s spread at certain (*) summer camps. A cure for this disease was the original aim of the charity March of Dimes. Polish-American scientist Albert Sabin developed an oral vaccine for this disease. For 10 points, name this disease that often causes childhood paralysis and whose vaccine was first created by Jonas Salk.
tossups.answer: polio [or Poliomyelitis]

tossups.question: Note to moderators: read answerline carefully. An “ancient” type of these instruments employed in gagaku ensembles has a size of 1.8 namesake units and was adapted from the Chinese xiāo (“shyao”). The third movement of the Yellow River Piano Concerto begins with a solo for one of these instruments, whose thin membrane gives it a distinctive buzzing sound. Unlike the dízi (“DEE-zeh”), the (*) shakuhachi is an end-blown type of these instruments. They’re not clarinets, but Theobald Boehm developed the key system for this instrument’s Western concert type. The “vessel” type of these instruments is exemplified by the ocarina. Many of these instruments are made of bamboo and may be vertical or transverse. For 10 points, name these woodwind instruments related to the piccolo.
tossups.answer: flute [accept vessel flutes or concert flutes; accept shakuhachi before read and prompt after; accept dízi before read and prompt after; prompt on woodwind]
tossups.metadata: Ivvone Zhou, Fine Arts - Music - Miscellaneous> ~28038~ <Editor: Ivvone Zhou

tossups.question: Deriving the electromagnetic wave equation involves the successive application of this statement and a similar statement that features a negative term. Taking the curl of a curl in an equation derived from the Biot–Savart law yields this statement under the magnetostatic approximation. A term equal to the change in the electric displacement field over time was (*) added to this statement by Maxwell. This statement equates [read slowly] “J-sub-f plus d-capital D-d-t with the curl of the H-field.” This statement relates the line integral along a curve through a magnetic field to its enclosed electric current. For 10 points, identify this law in Maxwell’s equations that was devised by the namesake of the SI unit of electric current.
tossups.answer: Ampère’s circuital law [or Ampère–Maxwell law] (The “similar statement” is Faraday’s law of induction.)
tossups.metadata: Lalit Maharjan, Science - Physics> ~28174~ <Editor: David Bass

tossups.question: Boethius defends the possibility of this property by analogizing God’s timelessness to the view from a mountain. Molinism holds that this property is possible because God has “middle knowledge” of counterfactuals. A theodicy named for this property argues that agents with this property are the source of evil, not God. Harry Frankfurt’s cases are counterexamples to the P·A·P, which states that a strong conception of this property is necessary for moral (*) responsibility. Theological fatalism argues that humans lack this property due to God’s infallible foreknowledge of our future. Compatibilism holds that determinism can coexist with this property. For 10 points, name this property of being able to choose one’s actions.
tossups.answer: free will [accept freedom of the will; accept libertarian free will or compatibilist free will]
tossups.metadata: Vincent Du, RMP - Philosophy> ~28453~ <Editor: Vincent Du

tossups.question: Peter Hessler’s book The Buried profiles this city’s informal zabaleen garbage collectors. In the 1920s, a houseboat in this city’s Kit Kat neighborhood owned by diva Mounira al-Mahdia hosted cabinet meetings. Overcrowding in this city has spurred one government to build the Iconic Tower in a new planned city called the New Administrative Capital. Many of this city’s embassies are located in an “old” section that emerged from the city of (*) Fustat. A series of 2011 protests occurred around this capital city’s Tahrir Square. A river divides this city from the four million residents of the city of Giza. For 10 points, name this city, the most populous on the Nile and capital of Egypt.
tossups.answer: Cairo [accept Greater Cairo; prompt on Fustat until read]
tossups.metadata: Michael Bentley, Geography - World> ~27720~ <Editor: Michael Bentley

tossups.question: In 2018, a statue of this person was discovered in the ruins of a harbor at Berenike in Egypt. Attempts to date this person’s life include Dotted Chronology, which is based on the Five Patriarchs, and a Corrected Long Chronology based on rock carvings. In 1998, the LTTE attacked a building housing this person’s left canine tooth. After stopping the sacrifice of goats, this person befriended King (*) Bimbisara of Magadha. A red sandstone statue of this person at Leshan is the tallest pre-modern statue in the world. This person, who was born in Lumbini as a member of the Shakya clan, had his body parts enshrined in stupas. For 10 points, name this prince who taught the Eightfold Path after gaining enlightenment.
tossups.answer: Siddhartha Gautama [accept the Buddha]
tossups.metadata: Ganon Evans, History - World - Asian> ~28363~ <Editor: Hari Parameswaran

tossups.question: Kirill Eskov’s alternate sequel to one of this author’s novels describes Haladdin’s journey to liberate humanity by destroying a mirror. This author’s Book of Lost Tales describes the destruction of two lamps and the creation of two trees after the “music of creation.” A posthumously published twelve-volume book described this author’s “Legendarium.” The walking song “The Road Goes Ever On” appears in this author’s first published novel, in which a (*) riddle contest is won by asking, “What have I got in my pocket?” On being heated, an object from this author’s novels displays two lines in Black Speech declaring its purpose to “rule them all.” For 10 points, name this author of The Lord of the Rings.
tossups.answer: J. R. R. Tolkien [or John Ronald Reuel Tolkien] (The unnamed works are The Last Ringbearer by Eskov and The Hobbit by Tolkien.)
tossups.metadata: Jim Fan, Literature - World and Miscellaneous> ~28049~ <Editor: Jim Fan

tossups.question: An Italian pioneer of this technology gave rise to a trend for “Lunardi skirts” in England. Enthusiasm for this technology in France diminished after a 1785 accident that killed Jean-François Pilâtre de Rozier (“zhahn-frahn-SWAH pee-LAH-twuh duh ROH-zee-ay”). It’s not the telegraph, but a Corps that used this technology to gather intelligence at the Battle of Antietam was led by Thaddeus S. C. Lowe. This technology powered bombs that killed six people in Bly, Oregon in the only fatal (*) Fu-Go long-distance attack during World War II. In France, this technology was pioneered by the Montgolfier brothers and later used by Léon Gambetta to escape the Siege of Paris. For 10 points, name this technology that Jean-Pierre Blanchard used in 1785 to float across the English Channel.
tossups.answer: hot air ballooning [accept Montgolfier balloons or hydrogen balloons or helium balloons; prompt on unpowered flight or aviation or hydrogen or helium or hot air; reject “Zeppelin” or “airship” or “rigid airship”]
tossups.metadata: Michael Bentley, History - Cross, Historiography, and Miscellaneous> ~28279~ <Editor: Michael Bentley

tossups.question: A player of this instrument composed “Davenport Blues,” and played an influential solo on the Trumbauer Orchestra’s version of “Singin’ the Blues.” The leaders of ODJB and the Creole Jazz Band played this instrument, the smallest to use a device named for Paddy Harmon. This instrument plays an 11-second cadenza at the start of “West End Blues.” A player of this instrument led ensembles that recorded (*) “Potato Head Blues” and “Heebie Jeebies.” King Oliver mentored a player of this instrument who recorded with the Hot Five and Seven and was nicknamed “Satchmo.” For 10 points, name this instrument played by Louis Armstrong.
tossups.answer: B-flat trumpet [accept cornet]
tossups.metadata: Victor Pavao, Fine Arts - Jazz> ~27289~ <Editor: Victor Pavao

tossups.question: The simultaneous cross-section for two of these particles is measured in units named for Maria Goeppert Mayer. Silicon quantum dots are sources of these particles. Marvin Minsky invented a device that fires these particles at planes through a pinhole to minimize the point spread function. Bleaching and quenching reduce these particles’ quantum efficiency so they’re harder to detect with (*) CCDs. In super-resolution techniques, these particles measure distances shorter than their 100-nanometer Abbé (“uh-BAY”) limit. Halogens react with tungsten filaments to provide these particles, which are absorbed and then re-emitted when a molecule fluoresces. For 10 points, name these particles provided by a microscope’s light source.
tossups.answer: photons [prompt on bosons or gauge bosons; prompt on radiation or light]
tossups.metadata: Adam Silverman, Science - Chemistry> ~27596~ <Editor: Adam Silverman

tossups.question: In a Goan celebration of this type, a copper pot and a green or saffron brocade are erected on bamboo poles and decorated with sugar crystals and mango leaves. Super-soakers are used during various mid-April “water festivals” coinciding with this type of celebration, as exemplified by the national Thai holiday of Songkran. Samanu is one of seven foods placed on haft-sin tables during this type of celebration, which begins following (*) Chahārshanbe Suri (“chah-har-SHAN-bay soo-REE”) and its bonfire jumping tradition. Nowruz is this type of celebration. During one of these celebrations, children receive red envelopes of cash. For 10 points, name these celebrations where Chinese dragon dances mark the start of the next zodiac year.
tossups.answer: New Year’s Day [accept Solar New Years; accept Chinese New Year or Lunar New Year; prompt on Spring festivals; prompt on Gudi Padwa; prompt on Nowruz or Navroz until read; prompt on harvest festival by asking “what other celebration coincides with it?”; prompt on the start of a new monsoon or rainy season; prompt on the end of the dry season] (The first line is Gudi Padwa.)
tossups.metadata: Abhinav Rachakonda, RMP - Other Religion> ~28138~ <Editor: Kevin Thomas

tossups.question: John Woodbridge published a collection potentially without this author’s knowledge that includes a poem addressed to a “dear Mother, fairest Queen.” This author described how the “strong foundation of proud Babel” supported the Assyrian empire in the first section of the long poem “The Four Monarchies.” This author bids adieu to all vanity in a poem describing how “My pleasant things in (*) ashes lie.” Love is valued over “whole mines of gold” and “all the riches the East doth hold” in a poem this author opened “if ever two were one, then surely we” and addressed to her “Dear and Loving Husband.” For 10 points, name this colonial poet of The Tenth Muse Lately Sprung Up in America.
tossups.answer: Anne Bradstreet [or Anne Dudley Bradstreet; prompt on Anne Dudley] (The first poem is “A Dialogue between Old England and New.”)
tossups.metadata: Ganon Evans, Literature - American - Poetry> ~28435~ <Editor: Chandler West

tossups.question: A 700-gigapixel image of this painting was published after a live-streamed restoration of it was completed under the leadership of Taco Dibbits in 2020. In 1975, a teacher slashed this painting, damaging a depiction of a man in it wearing yellow. A shield in this painting lists eighteen men who are represented elsewhere by a pistol called a klover. To fit into a city hall in 1715, this painting had its edges trimmed, damaging a (*) drummer who appears in front of a dog. The removal of a dark varnish from this painting illuminated a blue and yellow flag and a girl carrying a chicken. The Rijksmuseum’s (“RIKES-museum”) centerpiece is, for 10 points, what group portrait of a militia by Rembrandt?
tossups.answer: The Night Watch [or De Nachtwacht; accept Operation Night Watch; or The Shooting Company of Frans Banning Cocq; or Militia Company of District II under the Command of Captain Frans Banninck Cocq]
tossups.metadata: Ganon Evans, Fine Arts - Painting - European 1600-1945> ~27155~ <Editor: Chandler West

tossups.question: Organisms with this trait synthesize a properly spliced transcript of the transformer gene by expressing the Sxl (“S-X-L”) protein. Wolbachia (“woll-BACK-ee-uh”) infection drives up the number of mosquitoes that possess this trait, since only they are diploid. In mammals with this trait, dosage compensation is controlled by two long noncoding RNAs that coat DNA called Tsix (“T-six”) and (*) Xist (“X-ist”). Only Drosophila with this trait can be heterozygous for eye color. Mary Lyon explained how calico cats with this trait form Barr bodies. Humans with this trait are represented by circles on pedigrees and can be unaffected carriers of the allele for color blindness. For 10 points, having two X and no Y chromosomes corresponds to what biological trait in humans?
tossups.answer: female [or biological femaleness; accept XX until “two X” is read; prompt on women or girls; prompt on sex; prompt on diploid until it is read]
tossups.metadata: Adam Silverman, Science - Biology> ~27626~ <Editor: Adam Silverman

tossups.question: During a renaissance in this city, Anton Koberger printed an encyclopedic Chronicle. It’s not Aachen, but the Golden Bull of 1356 granted this city the right to host the first diet of a Holy Roman Emperor. Much later, 152 anti-aircraft searchlights were used to make a “cathedral of light” in this city. A speech given in this city by Julius Streicher to an audience of 700,000 appears in a (*) propaganda film by a woman who later directed Olympia. Some “subsequent” events in this city concerned the makers of Zyklon B. Robert H. Jackson represented US interests at an event in this city’s Palace of Justice that sentenced Hermann Göring to death. For 10 points, name this German city that hosted a series of Nazi war trials.
tossups.answer: Nuremberg [or Nurnberg]

tossups.question: In a play by this author, Jackie Croyton interrupts a game of adverbs-only charades; the central family of that play by this author likes to act out a scene from Love’s Whirlwind. In another play by this author, a woman passes out and is woken up with brandy before requesting that Irving Berlin’s song “Always” be played on a gramophone. In the last act of a play by this author, two couples sneak back to London after being subjected to the antics of the (*) Bliss family. A line in Percy Shelley’s “To a Skylark” titles a play by this author in which the ghost Elvira disrupts Charles Condomine’s marriage after a seance by Madame Arcati. For 10 points, name this British playwright of Hay Fever and Blithe Spirit.
tossups.answer: Noël Coward [or Sir Noël Pierce Coward]
tossups.metadata: Ethan Ashbrook, Literature - British - Drama> ~28091~ <Editor: Jim Fan

tossups.question: The effect of homophily on the dynamics of these things is studied in McPherson, Smith-Lovin and Cook’s paper “Birds of a Feather.” Real-world examples of these things with power law degree distributions are described as “scale-free.” Georg Simmel’s principle of triadic closure describes the tendency of triangular motifs to form in these things if B and C are both neighbors with A. Mark Granovetter studied job applicants to identify (*) “weak ties” in these things. The surprisingly low average path length in these structures, popularly just 6, is called the small-world phenomenon. Nodes representing individuals are connected by edges representing social connections in, for 10 points, what web-like models of social structure?
tossups.answer: social networks [accept scale-free networks or small-world networks; prompt on graphs by asking, “What do they represent?”]
tossups.metadata: Vincent Du, Social Science - Sociology> ~28163~ <Editor: Vincent Du

tossups.question: A company in this industry colloquially known as Poverty and Death operated a facility in Senghenydd (“SENG-hen-nith”) where 440 people were killed in October 1913. An alliance between workers in this industry and gay rights activists inspired the film Pride. On Vesting Day in 1947, one country nationalized this industry under the NCB. A 1973 strike in this industry prompted the Three-Day Week under the (*) Heath government. A union of workers in this industry fought the so-called Battle of Orgreave under the leadership of Arthur Scargill. The first commercial deployment of Thomas Newcomen’s steam engine was to pump water for this industry. For 10 points, the ironclad HMS Devastation was fueled exclusively from what industry’s outputs?
tossups.answer: coal mining [prompt on mining]

bonuses.leadin: An early group of these people sat in a shopfront and judged the attire of passersby in what the Duke of Wellington called a “mysterious and terrifying tribunal.” For 10 points each:
parts: Name this archetype exemplified by Beau Brummell, who claimed to take five hours to dress each morning.
A Bertram P. Matthews play about Brummell is best remembered for the incidental music composed by this British composer of the “Pomp and Circumstance” marches.

San Francisco rock band The Beau Brummels had some of their songs produced by this artist, notorious for arriving late to concerts. This man’s integrated band recorded the 1971 album There’s a Riot Goin’ On.
answers: Sly Stone [or Sylvester Stewart; accept Sly and the Family Stone]
bonuses.metadata: Yingzhi Nyang, Other - Other Academic and General Knowledge> ~22167~ <Editor: Michael Bentley

bonuses.leadin: Long-term administration of asthma medications like prednisone is an iatrogenic (“ai-ah-truh-JEN-ick”) cause of this disease. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this endocrine disorder that’s more often caused by adrenal tumors that overproduce an immuno·suppressive steroid hormone.
The most common cancer that causes Cushing’s is a benign tumor in this gland at the base of the brain, since it releases the ACTH that stimulates cortisol production.

Oddly, ectopic tumors of this non-endocrine organ may secrete ACTH and cause Cushing’s disease. Malignant carcinomas in this organ are classified with the labels “small-cell” or “non-small-cell” and can be caused by silicosis.
bonuses.metadata: Ganon Evans, Science - Biology> ~22163~ <Editor: Adam Silverman

bonuses.leadin: This man allegedly yelled “Do not disturb my circles!” upon being confronted by a Roman soldier. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this mathematician who was killed while studying geometry. He supposedly shouted “Eureka!” after discovering his law of buoyancy.

Archimedes was killed during the Roman siege of this city during the Second Punic War. Prior to the Second Punic War, this city in Magna Graecia (“GRAI-kee-uh”) was ruled by tyrants like Agathocles and Hieronymus.

The desecration of these sacred statues was considered a bad omen prior to Athens’s attempted siege of Syracuse. Alcibiades was accused of mutilating the genitalia on these statues prior to the expedition.
bonuses.metadata: Jeffrey Liu, History - European - Classical> ~23071~ <Editor: Hari Parameswaran

bonuses.leadin: This artist took offense at Bruno Alfieri’s description of his creative process in Time, sending a telegraph to the magazine stating, “NO CHAOS DAMN IT.” For 10 points each:
parts: Name this artist who was mentored on breaking free from the strictures of his teacher Thomas Hart Benton by the printmaker Stanley William Hayter. This alcoholic artist died in a car crash aged 44.
In the 1990s, conservators at MoMA unsuccessfully tried to recreate Pollock paintings by studying the films this German-American photographer made of Pollock at work.
Pollock was a central figure in this modern art movement, which was championed by the critic Clement Greenberg.
answers: Abstract Expressionism [or AbEx; accept action painting or gestural abstraction; prompt on the New York School; prompt on drip painting; prompt on abstract art or abstraction; reject “Expressionism”]

bonuses.leadin: Mollie Fancher was dubbed the “Brooklyn Enigma” for her ESP-like ability to read without sight while engaged in an extreme form of this practice. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this practice whose namesake Victorian-era “girls” developed supernatural powers. A holy “mirabilis” disorder is characterized by this practice performed by many religious women, including St. Catherine of Siena.
Saints like St. Catherine survived years of fasting solely consuming this substance which, through communion, becomes Christ’s body.
Fasting girls could manifest these features on their bodies that corresponded to Christ’s wounds. Padre Pio and St. Francis also developed these marks.
answers: fasting [or abstaining from food or self-starvation; accept fasting girls; accept anorexia mirabilis; prompt on dieting]
Holy Eucharist [accept the host; accept unleavened bread; accept communion wafers]
bonuses.metadata: Kevin Thomas, RMP - Christian Practice> ~22633~ <Editor: Kevin Thomas

bonuses.leadin: In a play, a character with this surname states “History is about to crack wide open. Millennium approaches.” For 10 points each:
parts: Give this surname of a ghost who tells Roy Cohn that he has been disbarred while on his deathbed. Sylvia Plath’s The Bell Jar opens during the “queer, sultry summer” when a couple with this surname were electrocuted.
The ghost of Ethel Rosenberg appears in this Tony Kushner play in which Prior Walter falls ill with AIDS.
This author fictionalized children of the Rosenbergs seeking justice in his novel The Book of Daniel. The pianist Coalhouse Walker is terrorized by racist firemen in a novel by this author.
answers: Rosenberg [or the Rosenbergs; accept Ethel Rosenberg or Julius Rosenberg; accept “the summer they electrocuted the Rosenbergs”]
Angels in America: A Gay Fantasia on National Themes [or Angels in America: Millennium Approaches; or Angels in America: Perestroika]
E. L. Doctorow [or Edgar Lawrence Doctorow] (The unnamed novel is Ragtime.)
bonuses.metadata: Ganon Evans, Literature - American - Misc> ~22866~ <Editor: Chandler West

bonuses.leadin: Verbal prods such as “you must go on” encouraged experiment participants to deliver this stimulus to a person complaining of heart pains. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this stimulus that participants believed they were administering as punishment in the Milgram obedience experiment.

Dogs laid down and accepted shocks in a study by Martin Seligman that coined the two-word term for this condition, in which people faced with repeated aversive stimuli stop resisting due to lack of control.

Periorbital shocks may be used to induce this reflex in a form of classical conditioning used to study motor learning. Jongkees and Colzato have linked the spontaneous rate of this reflex to dopamine activity.
answers: electric shocks [accept electrocution or word forms such as being electrocuted; prompt on electricity]
bonuses.metadata: Ganon Evans, Social Science - Psychology> ~23365~ <Editor: Vincent Du

bonuses.leadin: Emperor Gāozǔ stopped ripping off these peoples’ hats and peeing in them after Lù Jiǎ outlined how he should rule in the New Discourses. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these people who typically wore the Liáng Guān crown. The phrase “fénshū kēngrú” describes how Qín Shǐ Huáng would burn books and bury these people alive.
Lù criticized the Qín for failing to peacefully unify “all under [this place],” thus failing to achieve a “mandate” to rule named for this place.

Description acceptable. Lù convinced Gāozǔ that he could not rule in this physical manner. At the end of Ögedei’s conquests, Yēlǜ Chǔcái told the warlord not to rule in this physical manner and instead create a civil government.
answers: scholars [or Confucian scholars; or literati or wénrén; or mandarins or guān; prompt on civil servants or officials or bureaucrats; prompt on elites or gentry]
from horseback [accept obvious equivalents such as ruling from the saddle or from the back of a horse]
bonuses.metadata: Ganon Evans, History - World - Asian> ~22958~ <Editor: Hari Parameswaran

bonuses.leadin: In a work by this author, the tramp Luka briefly brings hope to Vaska, but disappears after Vaska kills the landlord Kostylyov (“cost-eel-YOFF”). For 10 points each:
parts: Name this author, who depicted destitute boarding house residents in his play The Lower Depths.
Gorky’s novel The Spy: The Story of a Superfluous Man uses a term popularized by this man’s novella The Diary of a Superfluous Man. This author wrote Fathers and Sons.

The Lower Depths ends with a character with this title informing the boarding house of the Actor’s suicide. Rudolf Erich Raspe created a character with this title and the name Munchausen, whose exploits include riding a cannonball.
bonuses.metadata: Michael Bentley, Literature - European - Drama> ~22138~ <Editor: Jaimie Carlson

bonuses.leadin: Between 2019 and 2023, a campaign in Bangladesh against the adulteration of turmeric with the lead salt of this ion probably saved a hundred thousand children’s lives. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this toxic inorganic ion which is widely used to dye turmeric because of its vivid yellow color.

Turmeric is also often adulterated with metanil yellow, which is normally used as one of these chemicals. Phenolphthalein (“FEE-nolff-THAY-leen”) is another of these chemicals that change color at the endpoint of a titration.
Metanil yellow can be detected by adding hydrochloric acid, which turns the fake turmeric this color. Phenolphthalein turns this color in base.
bonuses.metadata: Adam Silverman, Science - Chemistry> ~22944~ <Editor: Adam Silverman

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about Republican state legislatures pre-empting local laws, for 10 points each.
parts: Many local ordinances from Democratic cities in this state were squashed by a 2023 “Death Star Bill” signed by Governor Greg Abbott.
In 2023, Republicans in this Southern state seized control of the airport board in its capital. Flamethrower-wielding Congressman Andy Ogles represents this state, as does Senator Marsha Blackburn.

In 2022, one of these policies in Columbus was pre-empted with Ohio’s HB 430. One of these policies in St. Paul enacted in 2022 sets a max annual change of 3 percent and dramatically reduced demand for new construction permits.
answers: Tennessee [or TN] (It was a literal, not metaphorical, flamethrower.)
rent control policies [accept answers such as rent stabilization laws or rent ceilings; prompt on rent regulation or rent laws or eviction controls or price controls]

bonuses.leadin: In 1973, Per Enflo won a live goose for giving an example of a normed vector space with this property, but not the approximation property. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this property, which is weaker than compactness. Banach (“BAH-nuck”) spaces possess this property of spaces in which all Cauchy (“ko-SHEE”) sequences converge.

In 2023, Enflo published a generalization of his solution to the invariant subspace problem to complete inner product spaces, which are named for this mathematician. This mathematician gave an example in which guests can be moved up one room infinitely many times.
Hilbert’s Hotel illustrates this set of integers denoted with a double-struck “N.”
answers: David Hilbert (The example is Hilbert’s paradox of the Grand Hotel. When Felix Klein got the first car in Göttingen, he was not allowed to park in the spot closest to the Mathematics Institute, as that was already Hilbert’s space.)
bonuses.metadata: David Bass, Science - Math> ~22121~ <Editor: David Bass

bonuses.leadin: This photographer’s first solo exhibition depicted the Boston transgender community in works such as Ivy wearing a fall, Boston. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this photographer who depicted New York City’s “No wave” subculture in The Ballad of Sexual Dependency.

Goldin’s depiction of marginalized people in The Ballad of Sexual Dependency drew upon the work of this photographer whose works include Identical Twins, Roselle, New Jersey and an image of the “Jewish Giant” Eddie Carmel.

The Ballad of Sexual Dependency was originally conceived as a slideshow exhibition partly set to music by The Velvet Underground, which was once managed by this artist whose studio was known as The Factory.
bonuses.metadata: Wonyoung Jang, Fine Arts - Photography> ~22269~ <Editor: Chandler West

bonuses.leadin: A speaker with this occupation promises his love interest “Fair lined slippers for the cold, With Buckles of the purest gold.” For 10 points each:
parts: Name this occupation. In a poem later parodied by Walter Raleigh, a speaker with this occupation opens with the line “Come live with me and be my love.”
Edmund Spenser’s twelve-part poem The Shepheardes Calender echoed the Eclogues of this Latin author, who also wrote the Aeneid.
This author depicted Dorus, who disguises himself as a shepherd to woo Pamela, in The Countess of Pembroke’s Arcadia. This author described the moon’s “sad steps” in a 31st poem of a sonnet sequence.
answers: Philip Sidney (The unnamed poem is from Astrophil and Stella.)
bonuses.metadata: Michael Bentley, Literature - British - Poetry> ~22200~ <Editor: Jim Fan

bonuses.leadin: Sabine Hossenfelder’s book “Lost in [this field]” discusses how its “Beauty Leads Physics Astray.” For 10 points each:
parts: Name this general field whose advancements include Newton’s development of calculus.

In his Lecture on the principle of least action, Feynman motivates this field with “a new kind” of problem. This field of calculus finds paths corresponding to extreme values with tools like the Euler–Lagrange equation and the Beltrami identity.
Calculus of variations is used to minimize the time integral of the Lagrangian, which is the Legendre transform of this quantity. This quantity equals the total energy in a system.
answers: mathematics [accept maths or arithmetic; accept Lost in Math: How Beauty Leads Physics Astray]
calculus of variations [or variational calculus; prompt on variational methods]
bonuses.metadata: Lalit Maharjan, Science - Physics> ~23363~ <Editor: David Bass

bonuses.leadin: Crumbling walls and mysterious fires are blamed on one of these beings in the Omani oasis of Bahla. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these beings that may inhabit their eponymous “blocks’’ near Petra. Mental illness is sometimes attributed to possession by these beings of “smokeless fire.”
Many Egyptians attribute “jinn attacks” as the cause of this action’s namesake paralysis, which is also induced by the night hag and mare in Germanic lore.
Both sleep paralysis and SUNDs are attributed to the demonic batibat of this nation. In the 1950s, CIA agents in this country faked a string of vampiric aswang attacks to frighten off insurgents.
answers: The Philippines [or Pilipinas or Republic of the Philippines or Republika ng Pilipinas]
bonuses.metadata: Kevin Thomas, RMP - World Mythology> ~22714~ <Editor: Kevin Thomas

bonuses.leadin: In January 2024, Stéphen Rostain revealed lidar scans of road networks covered by the Amazon jungle in this country’s Upano Valley. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this modern-day country where conquistador Diego de Almagro founded its capital of Quito.

Caucheros in this industry exploited Indigenous Ecuadorians in the Amazon. The PAC’s abuses in this industry in Peru were chronicled by Roger Casement, who also wrote about abuses in this industry in Africa.
The Waorani people have sued this US company for dumping 18 billion gallons of waste in the Ecuadorian Amazon. A “doctrine” named for this company upheld the EPA’s ability to interpret legislation.
answers: Ecuador [or the Republic of Ecuador; or República del Ecuador; accept Ikwayur or Ikwayaur Ripuwlika or Ekuatur Nunka]
rubber industry [accept answers such as rubber harvesting or rubber collection]
Chevron [accept the Chevron Doctrine; accept Standard Oil Company of California or Standard Oil or Calso or Socal; prompt on Texaco]
bonuses.metadata: Ganon Evans, History - Cross, Historiography, and Miscellaneous> ~23077~ <Editor: Michael Bentley

bonuses.leadin: In an interview with Dua Lipa for her Service95 book club, this author described how his character Mariam realizes she lives in a “fantasy that she’s a meaningful member of a family.” For 10 points each:
parts: Name this Afghan author who chronicled life with the Taliban in A Thousand Splendid Suns and The Kite Runner.
Other authors championed by Dua Lipa include Min Jin Lee, who wrote this 2017 book that chronicles several generations of Sunja’s family, including the successful businessman Solomon.

A Chika Unigwe essay accompanied Dua Lipa’s interview with this author about a book in which Olanna encounters Kainene (“kai-NEH-neh”) at a refugee camp. This author of Purple Hibiscus described “The Danger of a Single Story” in a TEDx talk.
bonuses.metadata: Ganon Evans, Literature - World and Miscellaneous> ~23329~ <Editor: Jim Fan

bonuses.leadin: A 2013 bell-ringing ceremony at this site commemorated the 50th anniversary of the “I Have a Dream” speech. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this site that, in the early 2000s, was a relatively popular picnic site for Black families despite its massive carvings of Robert E. Lee, Stonewall Jackson, and Jefferson Davis.
Progress on Stone Mountain resumed following this 1954 Supreme Court decision whose follow-up case ordered desegregation “with all deliberate speed.”

Description acceptable. Georgia lawmakers guaranteed that “Stone Mountain shall never be altered” in exchange for one of these actions in 2001. A 1956 action of this type was part of Marvin Griffin’s “massive resistance” campaign.
answers: Brown v. Board of Education [accept in either order; accept Oliver Brown, et al. v. Board of Education of Topeka, et al. or Brown 1]
changing the state flag of Georgia [accept answers relating to adding or removing the Confederate battle flag or any other answer that reflects changes to the state flag]

bonuses.leadin: The score to this film features ominous nonsensical Latin chants, such as “I expected my feet to be clad with cymbals.” For 10 points each:
parts: Name this 1938 film set in Pskov whose score was adapted into a cantata. A pivotal section of this film ends with a descending trombone glissando to represent the drowning of invaders.
This composer depicted “The Battle on the Ice” in his soundtrack for Sergei Eisenstein’s film Alexander Nevsky. This Soviet composer created Peter and the Wolf.
Prokofiev drew from these texts to create the crusaders’ gibberish in Alexander Nevsky, possibly as a dig at his rival Igor Stravinsky’s “Symphony of” these texts.
answers: psalms [accept Book of Psalms; accept Symphony of Psalms; prompt on texts from the Vulgate Bible]
bonuses.metadata: Ganon Evans, Fine Arts - Music - 1900 to 1970> ~22454~ <Editor: Ivvone Zhou

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about the African American artist Archibald Motley, for 10 points each.
parts: Motley’s focus on realistic urban scenes was partly inspired by his studies under this Ashcan School artist, who depicted clothes lines above a busy street in his painting Cliff Dwellers.
Archibald Motley’s painting Nightlife hangs in this city’s Art Institute. This city also contains Grant Wood’s American Gothic.
A 1924 Motley painting depicts a woman peeling these fruits. These fruits are the most common subject of still lives by Paul Cezanne.
answers: apples [accept specific types like red or green apples]
